intro: Graphistylis organensis, commonly known as the Organ Mountains grass, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, tufted growth habit. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, wind-pollinated flowers. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and elevations above 6,000 feet. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
